Banan Chongqing 400054 China Carbon deposition or ‘coking’ reaction severely suppresses catalyst activity during the dry reforming reaction of methane (DRM). The MCM-41-loaded nickel catalyst (NM-C) prepared using the conventional impregnation method also faces these issues. In response, this study investigates a novel catalyst preparation approach employing N2 radio frequency (RF) discharge plasma coupled with surfactant (cetyltrimethylammonium bromide or CTAB) modification. Characterization of the resulting materials was conducted utilizing XRD, H2-TPR, CO2-TPD, TEM, XPS, TG-DTA, and other analytical techniques. Experimental findings reveal that both CTAB addition (NM-CTAB-C) and plasma-assisted catalyst preparation (NM-PN2h) outperform the conventional NM-C catalyst in the DRM. Notably, the catalyst prepared by the CTAB-assisted plasma method (NM-CTAB-PN2h) demonstrates significantly enhanced performance, with initial CH4 and CO2 conversions of 84.82% and 85.02%, respectively, at 700 °C. Compared to NM-C, NM-CTAB-PN2h exhibits improvements of 24.8% and 19.9% in CH4 and CO2 conversions, respectively. The Ni grain size of NM-CTAB-PN2h (4.9 nm) is notably smaller than NM-C (18 nm), indicating enhanced resistance to coking and stability during CO2 and methane dry reforming. After 20 h of reaction, NM-CTAB-PN2h maintains a particle size of 6.3 nm, significantly smaller than NM-C (21.4 nm). Moreover, NM-CTAB-PN2h exhibits remarkable resistance to carbon accumulation, with only a 2.36% weight loss compared to 23.38% for NM-C after 20 h at 700 °C. Utilization of CTAB-assisted plasma reduces Ni grain size, enhances metal-support interaction, and increases oxygen vacancies, thus improving dry reforming performance. graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Radio frequency plasma;CO2 CH4 dry reforming;Coke resistance;CTAB modified impregnation method Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The swift advancements in technology and economy characteristic of the contemporary epoch have led to a notable surge in carbon dioxide emissions. This presents a substantial environmental dilemma necessitating attention. To ameliorate the adverse effects of CO2 [1,2], it is crucial to explore more efficient systems for its conversion and utilization [3]. A promising avenue entails the dry reforming reaction of methane, or DRM, wherein CH4 and CO2 undergo a reforming process to yield hydrogen and carbon monoxide [4]. In this reaction, four elementary reactions are under scrutiny: the primary reaction (Eq. (1)) alongside three secondary reactions (Eq. (2)-4) [5]. Thermodynamic analysis has delineated the highly endothermic nature of the DRM reaction, demonstrating its increased favorability at elevated temperatures [6]. However, elevating the reaction temperature enhances stability at the cost of greater energy consumption. Conversely, reducing the reaction temperature exacerbates carbon accumulation. Current literature confines the temperature scope to the range of 873 K to 1123 K. Therefore, reforming catalysts confront the challenge of striking a balance between heightened activity and stability [5]. (1) C H 4 + C O 2 ↔ 2 C O + 2 H 2 Δ H 298 θ = 247 k J · m o l − 1 (2) C H 4 ↔ C + 2 H 2 Δ H 298 θ = 75 k J · m o l − 1 (3) 2 C O ↔ C + C O 2 Δ H 298 θ = − 172 k J · m o l − 1 (4) C O 2 + H 2 ↔ C O + H 2 O Δ H 298 θ = 41 k J · m o l − 1 Nickel-based catalysts are extensively utilized due to their superior catalytic activity compared to noble metal-based catalysts, as well as their cost-effectiveness and other benefits [7]. However, the stability of nickel-based catalysts is not ideal, as the active metal experiences severe coking and sintering at high temperatures, resulting in surface deactivation due to carbon deposition [8]. Recent years have witnessed extensive research efforts aimed at enhancing the resistance of nickel-based catalysts to coking and sintering, pivotal for bolstering their overall performance and stability [9]. Investigations have revealed that surface modification of the catalyst enhances its resistance to coking, offering crucial insights for designing a catalyst with both high activity and stability. Cetyltrimethyl-ammonium bromide (CTAB), a cationic surfactant commonly utilized in porosity and wettability tuning, has been found to play a pivotal role in improving catalyst activity and stability [10]. Studies by Wang et al. [11] showcased the successful synthesis of Ni/Ce catalysts with a high specific surface area by incorporating CTAB as a cationic surfactant, resulting in a significant reduction in Ni particle size compared to catalysts devoid of CTAB. Similarly, Muhammad et al. [12] observed substantially lower carbon deposition on catalysts incorporating CTAB, underscoring its efficacy in mitigating carbon buildup and thus preserving long-term stability and activity. CoCex composite catalysts prepared by Zhang et al. [13] CTAB as a templating agent demonstrated excellent catalytic performance in the DRM reaction. This technique offers a simplified novel approach, boasting environmental friendliness, economic viability, and cost-effectiveness. However, the particle size of Ni catalyst tends to increase significantly under high-temperature reaction conditions, posing challenges in further controlling coking reaction. Samrout et al. [14] observed a notable increase in particle population under high-temperature conditions, with the successful control of NiO particle size before the reaction resulting in a marked reduction in carbon deposit formation. These findings suggest the advantages of employing CTAB as a catalyst preparation modifier, albeit noting the increase in NiO particle size in the catalysts post-reaction. The utilization of plasma for catalyst preparation has rapidly garnered attention among researchers as a promising departure from conventional techniques [15]. Employing cold plasma in catalyst synthesis offers a potential remedy to common issues such as sintering and the formation of large particles. Cold plasma has attracted considerable interest due to its ability to decompose gasses at ambient temperature, along with its high conversion efficiency achieved through processes such as electron collision excitation, ionization, and dissociation [16]. Yu et al. [17] employed glow discharge plasma to fabricate the P-NiPt/MgAlO catalyst, resulting in a notable reduction in Ni metal size by 38.7% and a 65% increase in dispersion compared to the non-plasma-treated NiPt/MgAlO catalyst. Similarly, Jin et al. [18] synthesized Ni/Al2O3-P catalysts with dielectric barrier discharge plasma, showcasing exceptional stability and resistance to carbon deposition, with only 2.5% deposited carbon. This represents a significant decrease of 13.7% compared to conventionally prepared catalysts. Furthermore, plasma-assisted synthesis facilitated the formation of smaller Ni particles, measuring 4.4 nm, suggesting that plasma treatment of the precursor is an efficacious strategy for enhancing Ni dispersion and reducing particle size, thereby improving stability and resistance to carbon deposition. Leading from the above studies, this work delves into the fabrication of nickel-based catalysts supported on MCM-41 through the conventional impregnation technique, probing the impact of integrating CTAB and plasma treatment on catalyst efficacy. Emphasizing the cooperative and synergistic interplay of these methodologies, the investigation elucidates their effects on the structural attributes, reactivity, endurance, and resilience against coking reaction during the DRM reaction involving nickel-based catalysts. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation Preparation of CTAB-modified Ni catalyst by impregnation: typically a given amount of CTAB was dissolved in deionized water to achieve complete dissolution. In a molar ratio (CTAB:Ni) of 1:50), an appropriate amount of nickel nitrate (Ni(NO3)2) equivalent to 10 wt% Ni was added to the beaker under stirring. A quantitative amount of MCM-41 support was then dispersed uniformly into the solution. The solution was allowed to age at room temperature for Ni impregnation into the support for 45 min before placed into a temperature-controlled water bath at 80 °C for evaporative drying. The resultant green powder was then placed in an oven at 110 °C for 12 h to collect the precursor, NM-CTAB, the catalyst precursor without CTAB was designated as NM. and then calcined in a muffle furnace at 550 °C in the air for 4 h to collect the catalyst, NM-CTAB-C. Preparation of CTAB-assisted Ni catalyst by the plasma method: the precursors NM and NM-CTAB were placed in an RF plasma generator, with an output power of 200 W. The air inside the RF plasma generator is evacuated before nitrogen is injected to initiate the discharge. Where the catalyst underwent of N2 plasma treatment for various periods to obtain catalysts namely NM-CTAB-PNx (X = 1 h, 2 h, 3 h). 2.2 Catalyst evaluation A quantity of catalyst was placed in a continuous flow fixed bed reactor, the reactor was then placed vertically in the reactor and insulated by plugging the upper and lower ports with high temperature resistant quartz cotton. At 700 °C the catalyst particles were reduced with H2 at a gas flow rate of 16 mL · min-1 for 1.5 h. CH4 and CO2 gas mixture with a molar ratio of 1:1 was introduced into the reactor, and the reaction gas was introduced at an air velocity of GHSV=36,000 mL/g-1·h-1, the gas mixture of the reactants and products was introduced into a gas chromatograph (SC-3000B) to analyze the reactants and products. The conversion of CH4 and CO2, the yield of CO and CO/H2 were calculated using the following equations [19]. Equations are also given for H2 selectivity ( S H 2 ), CO selectivity ( S C O ) [20] and carbon balance [21]. Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectroscopy of the functional groups of the catalysts was tested using an IRTracer-100 spectrometer in the interval of 400–4000 cm-1 and using a resolution of 4 cm-1. Using X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, Thermo Scientific KAlpha+) the binding energies and elemental contents in the catalysts were investigated. The binding energy was also corrected using C1s (E b = 284.8 eV) as a standard. The reducibility of the catalysts was probed with H2-TPR/CO2-TPD using BSD-Chem 200. The catalysts were initially treated at 300 °C under argon for approximately 30 min, and then treated for 30 min after increasing the TPR measurement temperature to 800 °C at a ramp rate of 10 °C⋅min-1 under 10% H2/Ar. The alkalinity of the catalysts was investigated by CO2-TPD using a BSD-Chem 200 instrument. The morphology, structure, and particle size of the catalysts were characterized using transmission electron microscopy (TEM, JEOL JEM-F200, Japan), while the elemental distribution was recorded with electron spectroscopy. Carbon deposition on the reacted spent catalyst was analyzed and tested for the amount and type of carbon build-up using an STA2500 thermogravimetric analyzer. The test temperature was increased from room temperature to 800 °C under air atmosphere with an elevated heating rate of 10 °C/min. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 XRD analysis Catalyst crystallinity was first characterized with XRD. Fig. 1 (a) shows that the fresh catalyst (NM-C) has five distinct diffraction peaks associated with NiO at 37.35°, 43.39°, 63.08°, 75.54° and 79.63° in 2θ scale, matching with those nickel oxide (PDF#47–1049). The NiO particle sizes of fresh catalysts NM-C and NM-CTAB-C were determined as 17.3 and 7.5 nm, respectively, using Scherrer's equation. Notably, discernible nickel oxide diffraction peaks were absent in any of the catalysts treated with RF discharge plasma. Fig. 1(b) shows the XRD patterns of the reduced catalysts under H2 atmosphere. After the reduction, the catalyst NM-C exhibits three distinct diffraction peaks corresponding to Ni particles at 44.51°, 51.85°, and 76.37°, representing the Ni(111), Ni(200), and Ni(220) crystal planes, respectively [22]. The grain size of Ni was calculated using Scherrer's equation based on the strongest Ni(111) crystal surface, with results presented in Table 1 . The particle sizes of the NM-C and NM-CTAB-C catalysts are measured at 18.3 nm and 8.6 nm, respectively. The intensity of the characteristic diffraction peaks of nickel diminished in the NM-CTAB-C catalysts post-reduction, indicating that CTAB incorporation fosters improved dispersion of Ni species and a reduction in particle size. Subsequent to plasma treatment, the particle size of the NM-PN2h catalyst was measured at 5.3 nm. RF plasma treatment facilitated the infiltration of the active metal species into the porous space of the support, with the support scaffold effectively constraining the reduced Ni to maintain a diminutive particle size. The catalysts NM-CTAB-PN1h, NM-CTAB-PN2h, and NM-CTAB-PN3h, synthesized through CTAB-assisted N2 RF plasma, exhibit diffraction peaks at reduced intensity, with particle sizes of 5.8 nm, 4.9 nm, and 6.1 nm respectively. The results indicate that the duration of plasma treatment directly influences the particle size. As such, it is clear that the combination of CTAB incorporation and RF plasma treatment can result in much smaller particle sizes of Ni catalysts, conducive to mitigating particle agglomeration during high-temperature processing. 3.2 BET analysis The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms and pore size distribution curves of the catalysts can be seen in Fig. 2 , while the structural properties are presented in Table 1. Fig. 2(a) shows typical IV-type adsorption isotherms and H1-type hysteresis loops for all catalysts, indicating that they all maintained the mesoporous properties of MCM-41 [23]. Table 1 shows a significant difference in specific surface area and pore volume between the treated catalysts and the conventional catalyst NM-C, with a reduction in specific surface area observed. Notably, after 3 h of plasma treatment, the specific surface area was greatly reduced, and the average pore size increased to 9.35 nm, three times larger than that of the other catalysts. This can be attributed to the excessively long plasma treatment time [24], which altered the mesoporous structure of the catalysts and consequently changed the pore size. 3.3 H2-TPR analysis Fig. 3 presents the reduction profiles of the fresh catalyst. The calculated total H2 consumption for each sample is shown in Table 2 . reduction peaks observed between 300 and 450 °C correspond to nickel oxide reduction on the catalyst surface [25], while those between 450 and 600 °C signify reduction within the support framework [26,27]. The presence of a high-temperature reduction peak suggests a strong interaction between the active metal and support [28]. Notably, the NM-CTAB-C catalyst exhibits a higher high-temperature reduction peak compared to the conventional NM-C catalyst. This is attributable to improved metal oxide dispersion and reduced nanoparticle size facilitated by CTAB [29,30], enhancing the metal-support interaction. RF plasma-treated NM-PN2h catalyst shows a distinct low-temperature reduction peak at 280 °C due to plasma-induced formation of readily reducible nickel oxide, with a higher high-temperature reduction peak indicating enhanced nickel oxide infiltration into support pores. The NM-CTAB-PNx catalysts, synthesized via CTAB-assisted plasma, feature smaller nickel oxide particles, leading to easier reduction observable from a shift of the reduction peaks in the low-temperature range towards a lower temperature. Furthermore, the reduction peak in the high-temperature range shifts proportionally to a higher temperature with the plasma treatment duration, with NM-CTAB-PN2h and NM-CTAB-PN3h catalysts exhibiting higher peak temperatures than NM-PN2h, suggesting improved metal-support interaction and reduced active metal sintering. 3.4 CO2-TPD analysis CO2-TPD was employed to assess the catalyst's CO2 adsorption capability or alkalinity of the adsorption sites. Fig. 4 presents the results obtained from this analysis, showing the temperature ranges associated with different types of basic sites. The calculated total amount of CO2 adsorbed for each catalyst is listed in Table 2. Peaks observed at 50–128 °C signify weakly basic sites, while those at 220–550 °C and >550 °C indicate moderately and strongly basic sites, respectively [31]. All catalysts demonstrated peaks within the 50–128 °C range, indicating the presence of weakly basic sites on MCM-41-based catalysts [32]. Incorporating CTAB in the preparation of NM-CTAB-C catalysts results in more pronounced peaks at weakly basic sites compared to conventional NM-C catalysts. Additionally, NM-CTAB-C catalyst exhibits a higher peak intensity at moderately basic sites. The moderate basic strength of NM-CTAB-C catalyst was further enhanced after RF plasma treatment. NM-CTAB-PNx catalysts, synthesized via CTAB-assisted plasma, show more pronounced peaks corresponding to medium-strength basic sites compared to both NM-CTAB-C and conventional NM-C catalysts. Particularly, NM-CTAB-PN2h displays the most prominent peaks associated with medium basic sites, indicating its superior CO2 adsorption capacity and consequently enhanced catalytic reactivity. 3.5 TEM analysis The morphology and size distribution of catalyst nickel particles before the reaction were characterized in detail by TEM, as shown in Fig. 5 (a). The two-dimensional ordered mesoporous structure of MCM-41 is clearly visible. Ni atoms produce bright and dark contrasts relative to the carriers. The particle sizes of all catalysts were calculated and are listed in Table 1. Notably, NM-C exhibits significant inter-particle agglomeration, with an average NiO particle size of 18.1 nm. Fig. 5(b), (c), and (d) illustrate that plasma-enhanced and CTAB-modified catalysts reduce agglomeration to some extent. In particular, Fig. 5(d1) shows almost no visible NiO agglomeration. MCM-41 exhibits disordered structures in NM-PN2h and NM-CTAB-PN2h, indicating that high-energy electron bombardment disrupts the mesoporous structure of the molecular sieves. The elemental EDS-mapping plots in Figure S5 further confirm the uniform distribution of Ni, Si, and O elements in the catalysts, indicating good dispersion. These results suggest that CTAB-coupled RF plasma produces smaller Ni particles with improved dispersion, aligning well with XRD findings. The smaller, well-dispersed Ni particles enhance the utilization of active metal Ni, contributing to improved catalyst stability and coking resistance. 3.6 FT-IR analysis Fig. 6 depicts Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectroscopy results for various catalysts within the 400–4000 cm-1 range, enabling scrutiny of support-active component interaction. NM-C, the conventional catalyst, exhibits notable peak intensities post-infrared testing. Peaks at 457 cm-1 correspond to tetrahedral bending vibration of Si-O-Si, while 805 cm-1 signifies asymmetric stretching motion of Si-O-Si backbone. Additionally, peaks at 960 cm-1 represent Si-O stretching vibration within Si-OH group, 1085 cm-1 denotes symmetric motion of Si-O-Si within skeleton, and 1245 cm-1 signifies Si-O-Si stretching vibration [33,34]. A peak at 1389 cm-1 is linked to OH stretching vibrations [35]. Introduction of CTAB in NM-CTAB-C catalyst yields reduced peak intensities compared to NM-C, which is attributable to enhanced Ni particle dispersion facilitated by CTAB. Further reduction in the peak intensity occurs in NM-PN2h post-RF plasma treatment, which may be associated with the better dispersion of Ni particles and the perturbing support structure by plasma treatment. Peaks below 1000 cm-1 mostly pertain to support surface groups, primarily Si-OH, Si-O-Si, and Si-O-Si vibrations, suggesting plasma treatment significantly reduces OH content on catalyst surfaces and O atop supports, favoring conversion of surface structural oxygen into adsorbed oxygen conducive to anti-coking. NM-CTAB-PNx catalysts synthesized via CTAB-assisted plasma consistently exhibit lower peak intensities than NM-C, indicating plasma treatment duration's critical role in achieving optimal results, with longer durations generally enhancing individual peak intensities. Notably, NM-CTAB-PN2h displays lowest intensity among all peaks, suggesting enhanced resistance to carbon accumulation. 3.7 XPS analysis XPS spectroscopy was employed to analyze the valence states and distribution of Ni and O elements. Fig. 7 (a) illustrates distinct Ni 2p3/2 valence peaks and accompanying satellite peaks for all catalysts [36], indicating the presence of NiO species in both calcined and plasma-treated samples. Table 3 shows a progressive increase in nickel 2p3/2 binding energy peak intensity across catalysts, with NM-CTAB-PN2h exhibiting the highest intensity, suggesting strongest interaction between NiO species and support in this catalyst. Fig. 7(b) presents the O 1 s curves for all catalysts, primarily consisting of the Ni-O species at 530 eV, the Si-O species at 532 eV, and surface adsorbed oxygen species (Oads) at 534 eV [37]. Incorporation of CTAB and plasma treatment augmented surface adsorbed oxygen content, with NM-CTAB-PN2h exhibiting the highest. This enhancement, attributed to altered lattice conditions post-plasma treatment, aligns with FT-IR characterization results. Higher adsorbed oxygen favors catalyst's anti-carbon deposition performance, facilitating carbon deposition elimination during reaction [38]. 3.8 Catalytic performance of the catalysts All catalysts underwent a stability assessment in the dry methane reforming reaction at 700 °C for 20 h, with results depicted in Fig. 8 , revealing significant disparities. The conventional catalyst, NM-C, displayed low initial conversion rates and stability, initiating at 60.00% for CH4 and 66.11% for CO2, with sharp declines of 30.59% and 22.13% observed over the stabilization period. This decline may stem from active metal agglomeration, sintering, and coke deposition, hastening deactivation. Incorporating the surfactant CTAB into NM-CTAB-C catalyst enhanced initial CH4 and CO2 conversion rates by 18.19% and 13.89%, respectively, compared to NM-C. Additionally, CTAB introduction slightly improved catalyst stability. Plasma treatment was adopted to address stability issues, with NM-PN2h catalyst, subjected to a two-hour treatment, exhibiting notable stability, with CH4 and CO2 conversion rates decreasing by 9.1% and 15.06%, respectively, after the stabilization period. NM-CTAB-PNx catalysts, synthesized via CTAB-coupled RF plasma, demonstrated consistent activity stability, with NM-CTAB-PN2h emerging as the most effective, achieving CH4 and CO2 conversion rates of 84% and 85.02%, respectively. The selectivity of the catalysts H2 and CO is shown in Figure S3. The theoretical molar ratios of CO/H2 are 1:1 under ideal conditions. However, in practice, the reverse water-gas shift (RWGS) reaction takes place, which consumes H2 [39]. As a result, the actual molar ratios of CO/H2 produced during this reaction exceeds one. Fig. 8(d) shows that the carbon balance value for NM-C is approximately 85%, indicating that the reaction has just begun and some carbon accumulation has occurred. As the reaction progresses, this balance value decreases slightly, suggesting that the accumulated carbon may cover the active nickel sites, leading to gradual catalyst deactivation. In contrast, the carbon balance values for the modified catalysts approached 100%, indicating minimal carbon accumulation during the reaction. XRD characterization results for the spent catalysts support this finding. 3.9 XRD analysis of spent catalysts XRD characterization was conducted on the post-reaction catalyst to assess grain size variations. Fig. 9 illustrates the analysis results, revealing distinct diffraction peaks of Ni at 2θ angles of 44.50°, 51.86°, and 76.39°, corresponding to Ni (111), Ni (200), and Ni (220) grain surfaces, respectively. Both NM-C and NM-CTAB-C catalysts exhibited a significant increase in Ni (111) crystal particle size after the reaction. The particle size of reacted NM-C catalyst increased by 16.94%, reaching 21.4 nm, with a notable peak at 26.80° indicating graphitic carbon deposition. Conversely, NM-CTAB-C catalyst particle size after the reaction was 15 nm, a 74.42% increase compared to its size after reduction, suggesting agglomeration or sintering during the reaction, possibly leading to coke deposition and rapid deactivation. After NM-PN2h reaction of RF plasma-treated catalyst, Ni (111) particle size increased to 7 nm from the initial size after H2 reduction, which was 5.3 nm. NM-CTAB-PNx catalysts, synthesized via CTAB-coupled plasma, showed minimal increases in particle size, measuring 6.7 nm, 6.3 nm, and 7.6 nm for NM-CTAB-PN1h, NM-CTAB-PN2h, and NM-CTAB-PN3h, respectively. Initially, particle sizes decreased and then increased with prolonged treatment time, likely due to the generation of additional small nickel species susceptible to sintering at high temperatures over extended periods. NM-CTAB-PN2h exhibited the smallest particle size among the three catalysts, with only a 1.4 nm increase compared to its pre-reaction size. This suggests that 2 h of CTAB-coupled plasma treatment was optimal for achieving smaller particle sizes, improved dispersion, and enhanced resistance to agglomeration and sintering. 3.10 TG-DTA analysis of spent catalysts Fig. 10 illustrates TG-DTA test results for the reacted catalysts, while Table 4 presents corresponding weight loss in various temperature intervals. All catalysts displayed minor weight loss at 50–100 °C, primarily due to water evaporation. An upward trend in TG curves at 300–350 °C suggested nickel metal oxidation at high temperatures. Substantial weight loss in TG curves at 450–700 °C indicated graphitic carbon degradation [40]. DTA analysis revealed minor exothermic peaks near 330 °C and more prominent peaks around 650 °C, indicative of multiple coke deposits on catalyst surfaces, possibly leading to carbon nanotube formation and catalyst deactivation [16]. NM-C exhibited the highest weight loss of 23.38% and prominent exothermic peaks, confirming severe carbon buildup. NM-CTAB-C showed a 14% decrease in weight loss compared to NM-C but still displayed noticeable high-temperature exothermic peaks in DTA. NM-PN2h, prepared by RF plasma, exhibited significantly reduced weight loss of 2.67% and diminished high-temperature DTA peaks, addressing excessive weight loss and carbon accumulation issues. NM-CTAB-PNx catalysts, subjected to CTAB and RF plasma treatment, exhibited lower weight loss and reduced high-temperature DTA peaks compared to NM-C, effectively controlling carbon buildup. Optimal results were observed with a 2-hour treatment, yielding the lowest weight loss rate of 2.36%, highlighting CTAB coupled with 2-hour plasma treatment as the most effective parameter for inhibiting carbon deposition, consistent with post-reaction XRD results. Integrating the XRD and TEM results (Fig. 1, Table 1, Fig. 5) demonstrates that the grain size of NM-C is significantly large, attributed to the interaction between the abundant Si-OH groups on the MCM-41 surface and the reactive metal hydroxide [41]. This interaction leads to uneven dispersion of the Ni(OH)₂ precursor and subsequent nickel agglomeration. The addition of CTAB is effective in controlling particle size as CTAB is a surfactant that ionizes into cations (CTA⁺) when dissolved in water [42]. These CTA⁺ ions can easily electrostatically interact with certain crystalline anions, such as OH⁻, facilitating the self-assembly of precursors and enhancing Ni dispersion on the MCM-41 surface. The gas temperature during cold plasma treatment is typically maintained below room temperature; however, electrons can attain temperatures between 10,000 and 100,000 K [43]. As a result, this lack of thermal effects in the plasma fosters rapid nucleation and slow crystal growth, ultimately leading to smaller NiO sizes. H2-TPR results (Fig. 3) indicate that CTAB-coupled plasma treatment enhances Ni-O-Si interactions and inhibits the direct migration of active ingredients at elevated reaction temperatures. Consequently, this method yields Ni with a small size(4–8 nm). The reduced Ni size minimizes the formation of deposited carbon, prevents serious sintering of the Ni at high temperatures, and suggests that catalyst stability can be improved by mitigating carbon accumulation and sintering [16]. This was confirmed by catalyst performance tests (Fig. 8) and TG-DTA analysis (Fig. 10). FT-IR and XPS analyses of CTAB-coupled plasma (Figs. 6 and 7, and Table 3) indicated an increase in the generation and density of Oads on the catalyst surface, particularly for the NM-CTAB-PN2h catalyst, which exhibited the highest increase of 2.66%. This enhancement improved its CO2 adsorption capacity, aligning with CO2-TPD results (Fig. 4), and contributed to the removal of carbon deposits [44]. These findings are consistent with TG-DTA test results. The performance of the NM-CTAB-PN2h catalyst investigated in this study was compared with other Ni-based catalysts in Table 5 . The results clearly demonstrate that the NM-CTAB-PN2h catalyst exhibits high conversion rates (CH4 = 85%, CO2 = 85%) at 700 °C, with Ni particles of a minuscule size of 4.9 nm. Additionally, carbon accumulation was only 2.36% after a 20-hour DRM reaction. These findings highlight the strong stability and high activity of catalysts prepared using CTAB-coupled plasma. 4 Conclusion In this study, CTAB was utilized in conjunction with N2 radiofrequency plasma treatment to facilitate catalyst preparation for the DRM reaction. TEM and XRD analyses revealed that the Ni particle size in the NM-CTAB-PN2h catalyst was significantly smaller than that in the conventional NM-C catalyst, indicating a highly dispersed distribution of Ni species on the MCM-41 support. Consequently, NM-CTAB-PN2h demonstrated superior catalytic activity, achieving methane and carbon dioxide conversions of 84.82% and 85.02%, respectively. BET results indicated catalyst successfully preserved the mesoporous properties of MCM-41 following plasma treatment for a suitable duration. TPR results indicated improved interaction between the active component and support in the CTAB-coupled plasma-prepared catalyst, leading to reduced sintering during the 700 °C stability test. XPS analysis identified abundant adsorbed oxygen in NM-CTAB-PN2h, preventing carbon accumulation, while CO2-TPD results demonstrated strong basic sites for the CO2 reaction. TG characterization confirmed these findings, with NM-CTAB-PN2h accumulating only 2.36% carbon after a 20-hour reaction. Adjusting the particle size of Ni species using CTAB and N2 plasma resulted in smaller Ni nanoparticle sizes, enhanced interaction forces, and higher alkalinity, effectively preventing carbon deposition and ensuring sustained stability and resistance to carbon accumulation. coredata.dc:description: Carbon deposition or ‘coking’ reaction severely suppresses catalyst activity during the dry reforming reaction of methane (DRM). The MCM-41-loaded nickel catalyst (NM-C) prepared using the conventional impregnation method also faces these issues. In response, this study investigates a novel catalyst preparation approach employing N2 radio frequency (RF) discharge plasma coupled with surfactant (cetyltrimethylammonium bromide or CTAB) modification. Characterization of the resulting materials was conducted utilizing XRD, H2-TPR, CO2-TPD, TEM, XPS, TG-DTA, and other analytical techniques. Experimental findings reveal that both CTAB addition (NM-CTAB-C) and plasma-assisted catalyst preparation (NM-PN2h) outperform the conventional NM-C catalyst in the DRM. Notably, the catalyst prepared by the CTAB-assisted plasma method (NM-CTAB-PN2h) demonstrates significantly enhanced performance, with initial CH4 and CO2 conversions of 84.82% and 85.02%, respectively, at 700 °C. Compared to NM-C, NM-CTAB-PN2h exhibits improvements of 24.8% and 19.9% in CH4 and CO2 conversions, respectively. The Ni grain size of NM-CTAB-PN2h (4.9 nm) is notably smaller than NM-C (18 nm), indicating enhanced resistance to coking and stability during CO2 and methane dry reforming. After 20 h of reaction, NM-CTAB-PN2h maintains a particle size of 6.3 nm, significantly smaller than NM-C (21.4 nm). Moreover, NM-CTAB-PN2h exhibits remarkable resistance to carbon accumulation, with only a 2.36% weight loss compared to 23.38% for NM-C after 20 h at 700 °C. Utilization of CTAB-assisted plasma reduces Ni grain size, enhances metal-support interaction, and increases oxygen vacancies, thus improving dry reforming performance.

coredata.dc:title: CTAB-assisted radio frequency discharge plasma treatment enhances catalytic activity at sustained coking resistance of Nickel-based catalysts for CO2/CH4 reforming reaction
